comment.author: 27331537@N06
32162360@N00
47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You may find the following book of particular interest - Children of the Back Lanes: Destitute & Neglected Children in Colonial New South Wales by John Ramsland (NSW University Press, 1986), especially the section "The Ragged School movement in Sydney", pp. 90-103. The main difference from the existing paternal movements, is that instead of removing the children from the "corrupting influences" of their environments, and placing them in all-protecting asylums cut-off from the outside world, they sought to achieve reform within the context of the children's family and neighbourhood.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks for that. I did a bit of Troving and found more Victorian lofty ideals and worthy causes. The best contemporary explanation was at the Annual Meeting - SMH 4/9/1877 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13399436 . Also found a date for the building; (the Heritage NSW site (link above on first comment) says unknown) - 1874 - see SMH 7/8/1874 p.5 (near foot of page) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13338679
"The construction of the Ragged School, in Harrington-Street, has been commenced under the supervision of Mr.Albert Bond [City Architect]. When completed the building will consist of a large room 40 feet by 24 feet, of suitable design to the purposes for which it is intended. It will have a very taking elevation, though unpretentious, and will be relieved by the introduction of coloured briok work."
The Ragged Schools bricks ('full size spotted Sandstock"!!) were put up for auction and the building was due for demolition on 4/1/1910 - see "JAMES COWAN" advert SMH 24/12/1909 p.8 Col.7 (near the bottom of page) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15105117 [What did we all do before Flickr and Trove ?!]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a similar photo in the City of Sydney ArchivePix (search for Ragged School) which shows the school still standing when the wonderful c.1823 house and cooperage had been demolished.  Dated c.1909-1913.

comment._content: And one more, not yet on Flickr - Strangely, each picture has a different number of barrels outside the c.1822 house, which implies they were taken at different times / dates (as do the shadows).
